conversation.text: Hi there! How are you today?
Good. Can you teach me how to make cream soup?
Of course, are you making this for a certain occasion?
No. Why do you ask?
I was just wondering if there was a certain occasion or flavour of soup that you were wanting to make? Do you have a preference?
Can you name a few so that I can choose?
Of course, we could go through a mushroom soup, basic cream soup, a chicken soup or a broccoli soup.
Basic please.
Brilliant, would you like me to give you an ingredients list or go straight into the recipe?
An ingredient list.
Of course. You will need 6 cups of semi skimmed milk
That's it? Is that all I need?

Sorry I pressed send too quick. You will also need 3 tablespoons of plain flour, 3 tablespoons of butter, 3 quarters of a tablespoon of salt and the same amount of black pepper and minced garlic. You will then need 3 cups of your choice of vegetable and 1 tablespoon of cornstarch. Please also use a pan and mixing bowl.
Thanks! Since I have prepared the ingredients, shall we go through the recipe quickly?
Of course! First, please melt all of your butter into a large pot on your hob. Do this by turning your burner onto a medium heat. Melt and stir the butter occasionally with a wooden spoon.
What do I do after?
Next, please add your flour mixture to the melted butter. Do this buy adding 3 tablespoons to this mixture, but do this 1 tablespoon at a time and mixing between each addition.
No problem. What's next?
Once all of the flour is added, whisk until combined into a thick paste. This is called your roux and will help to thicken your soup!
evidence: Stir or whisk the mixture until there are no more clumps of flour.

conversation.text: I see. Can I eat it now?

Not yet, you will then need to leave your pan on the hob over your medium heat and add your milk into the mixture.However, do this by adding one cupful of milk at a time and whisk between each one. This helps to avoid lumps in the mixture.
evidence: Whisk 6 cups (1,400 mL) of milk into the roux.
Whisk 6 cups (1,400 mL) of milk into the roux.

conversation.text: How many times do I add the milk?
You will need to add your 6 cups of milk, one at a time. Whisking between each one. If you wanted a creamier soup the you could substitute one of the cupfuls of milk for 1 cup of cream also.
Alright. What's next?
You can now add the rest of your ingredients from your ingredients list. Will you be using vegetables or meat in your soup?
evidence: Put the other ingredients and seasonings into the pot.

conversation.text: Vegetables I suppose.
What vegetables will you be using?
evidence: Put the other ingredients and seasonings into the pot

conversation.text: Tomatoes and broccoli.
Sounds delicious! you can add these into your mixture now, we recommend about 200g of vegetables for this recipe. Also, add in your salt, pepper and minced garlic now.
Sure! What do I do after?

You will need to allow this mixture to boil on a high heat until it thickens. You will be able to see this happening, but it should take 3-5 minutes.  Whilst this is thickening, stir continuously to avoid burning the mixture. Once thickening has happened, turn down your heat to the lowest setting and simmer the soup on the low heat for 15-20 minutes.
evidence: Boil the soup until the liquid thickens,

conversation.text: Okay, can you tell me what else I need to do after 20-minute waiting?
Once this has happened, it will be ready to eat! Will you be eating this straight away?
Yes, I cannot wait to enjoy it lol!
Who will you be sharing this with?
evidence: Eat the soup right away, o

conversation.text: Just me.
This makes a big batch so you may want to transfer anything that you don't eat right away into a resealable container for a later day!
evidence: If you want to save the soup for later

conversation.text: Thank you for your help! Bye!
This will also keep in your freezer for 5 months if you have any left to be stored!
evidence: Cream soups will last for 3 to 4 days in the fridge and for about 5 months in the freezer.

procedure.summary: Melt the butter in a heavy pot on the stovetop.
procedure.description: Add 3 tablespoons (60 grams) of butter to a large pot. Turn the heat on the burner to medium, and let the butter melt completely. Stir the butter occasionally with a long-handled spoon. Sub out the butter for 3 tablespoons (44 mL) of cooking oil if you prefer. Extra virgin olive oil, vegetable oil, coconut oil, and other oil alternatives will work just fine!

procedure.summary: Add flour to the pan and stir it to combine it with the butter.
procedure.description: Measure out 3 tablespoons (25 grams) of flour, and add it 1 tablespoon (8 grams) at a time to the butter. Stir or whisk the mixture until there are no more clumps of flour. Repeat this process until all the flour has been added to the pot. This creates a roux. You generally use the same amounts of fat and flour to create a roux.

procedure.summary: Whisk 6 cups (1,400 mL) of milk into the roux.
procedure.description: Keep the heat on medium, and add the milk to the pot 1 cup (240 mL) at a time. Whisk the mixture to fully incorporate all the ingredients together. If you don’t want to use milk, substitute it for the same amount of either chicken or vegetable broth. You could also do a half-and-half mixture of milk and broth. For an even creamier texture, sub out 1 cup (240 mL) of milk for 1 cup (240 mL) of cream.

procedure.summary: Put the other ingredients and seasonings into the pot.
procedure.description: In general, use about 3 cups (500 to 600 grams) of your vegetable or meat of choice. Also, add 3/4 teaspoon (4 grams ) of salt, 3/4 teaspoon (1.5 grams) of black pepper, and 3/4 teaspoon (1.5 grams) of minced garlic to the pot at this time. For example, if you’re making cream of broccoli and mushroom soup, add 2 cups (400 grams) of chopped broccoli and 1 cup (200 grams) of diced mushrooms to the pot. You can follow a recipe or make up your own proportions.

procedure.summary: Boil the soup until the liquid thickens, or for about 3 to 5 minutes.
procedure.description: Turn the heat on the burner up to high to bring the liquid to a boil. Let it boil for several minutes, or until you notice the mixture is starting to thicken. Stir the soup occasionally to keep it from burning on the bottom. If your soup still seems runny after the 5 minutes of boiling, add some cornstarch to it. Mix 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of cold water and 1 tablespoon (9 grams) of cornstarch together first in a small bowl, and then add that to the soup. Stir the soup for several minutes as the cornstarch starts to thicken the mixture.

procedure.summary: Simmer the soup for an additional 15 to 20 minutes.
procedure.description: Reduce the heat to medium-high so that the soup is gently simmering (if there are bubbles popping on the surface of the soup, the temperature is up too high). Stir the pot every couple of minutes to prevent the bottom from burning. If you added vegetables to the soup, they’ll soften up nicely during this time.

procedure.summary: Eat the soup right away, or save it to use in future recipes.
procedure.description: If you want to eat the soup right away, ladle out however much you want into a bowl and enjoy! If you want to save the soup for later or to use in other recipes, turn the heat on the stove off and let the soup cool down for about 20 minutes. Then transfer the soup into a resealable glass container and store it in the fridge. When you’re ready to use it, simply reheat it on the stove or put it in the microwave for 4 to 5 minutes. Cream soups will last for 3 to 4 days in the fridge and for about 5 months in the freezer.
